drivers.name: cdj500
drivers.comments: This driver is available in the Ghostscript Printer Application

drivers.name: hpdj
drivers.comments:
Martin Lottermoser's general-purpose PCL 3+ Ghostscript driver. The development of this driver is continued under the name "pcl3". This database entry serves for the case that your distro has the "hpdj" driver compiled into Ghostscript and you do not want to recompile it to get "pcl3" into it. If you compile Ghostscript you should prefer to directly use "pcl3".

It is known to work reasonably well with a wide assortment of PCL DeskJets. This driver has many options; be sure to consult the man page gs-hpdj(1) for more information.

For many printers, the HPIJS driver may produce better color output.

drivers.name: hplip
drivers.comments:
This driver is available in the HPLIP Printer Application

HP Linux Imaging and Printing (HPLIP) is an HP-developed solution for printing, scanning, and faxing with HP inkjet and laser based printers in Linux. The HPLIP project provides printing support for over 3000 printer models, including Deskjet, Officejet, Photosmart, PSC (Print, Scan, Copy), Business Inkjet, Envy, NeverStop, Smart Tank, Tango, DesignJet, (Color) LaserJet, Mopier, Edgeline MFP, and LaserJet MFP.

Note that most HP models are supported, but a few are not. See Supported Devices at the HPLIP website for more information.

HPLIP is free, open source software distributed under the MIT, BSD, and GPL licenses. HP does not provide formal consumer or commercial support for this software.

HPLIP contains two flavors of the printer driver. The default driver is the CUPS Raster driver "hpcups" and as alternative the older IJS-based HPIJS driver is still available, but its development and support has been discontinued. In addition there are ready-made PPD files for all supported PostScript printers, so that they get used in PostScript mode. HPLIP ships updated PPD files for all HP printers and both driver flavors. Therefore we do not provide PPD files here. For non-HP printers which work with HPIJS we provide PPDs via the driver entries "hpijs-pcl3", "hpijs-pcl5e", "hpijs-pcl5c".

drivers.name: pcl3
drivers.comments:
This driver is available in the Ghostscript Printer Application

Martin Lottermoser's general-purpose PCL 3+ Ghostscript driver, successor of the "hpdj" driver.

It is known to work reasonably well with a wide assortment of PCL 3 inkjet printers. This driver has many options (enter the command "man gs-pcl3" in a terminal window to get more information), so you can do a lot of fine-tuning, but do not expect perfect results with the default settings. Due to being able to set so many different options separately you can even make rather exotic non-HP printers printing. To find out their options you print into a file under Windows and then apply the "pcl3opts" command (comes with the driver) on the file. It returns the Ghostscript command line which most probably prints in the mode of the printer for which your file was generated under Windows.

This patch adapts the driver to GPL/AFPL Ghostscript 8.x. In ESP Ghostscript 8.x this driver is already included.

Unfortunately, GNU Ghostscript 5.50 (and also ESP Ghostscript 5.50.1) has a bug which often causes segmentation faults when high amounts of memory are needed (high resolutions, Floyd-Steinberg dithering). A workaround is to use Ghostscript's "-dMaxBitmap=value" option with "value" being the size of memory which Ghostscript should be allowed to allocate for rendering one page. Try values of 40000000 and higher. In the foomatic config files there is the option "Memory Limit" to control this. Note that Ghostscript can take up memory up to the given amount. So be sure that you have enough swap space and note that your machine will slow down considerably during the rendering process. This problem does not appear with GNU or Alladin Ghostscript 6.x and newer.

For many printers, the gutenprint driver and the drivers from HP may produce better color output.

notes:
For basic printing functionality use the HPIJS driver . For advanced functionality such as printer status and maintenance features, use the HPLIP driver (which includes HPIJS).

600 dpi in colour is not supported by the hardware.

Portable printer, does 600x600 in bw and 600x300 in colour.

If you need a portable printer with a higher output quality, you should take the Canon BJC-50/55/80/85.

Michael Sweet, author of CUPS wrote about this printer:

You can't get high quality out of the 350 *at all*. Not even under Windows. I had one in our lab for about a month. We sent it back rather than keeping the printer because it looked so bad. IIRC it only prints at 300 DPI; a driver for the DeskJet 500C is the best match...

(What do you expect? It's a portable printer.)
